regulation_detail: Port of Rotterdam Authority (PRA) manages the Port of Rotterdam, prioritizing sustainability and efficient/safe services, and digitalization.

Mandatory Electronic Notification to Harbour Master (EKH) via PortBase Vessel Notification is required for vessel arrival at Port of Rotterdam, 24 hours prior to arrival (48 hours for Eurogeul >17.40m draught).
PortBase Vessel Notification (EKH) requires EORI number, Customs permit for electronic message traffic, and Port Authority ID for Port of Rotterdam.
Port of Rotterdam Authority emphasizes Port Call Optimisation (PCO) to standardize arrival and departure times for efficient vessel visits.

Key arrival documents (via 'Forms and checklists' section on Port of Rotterdam website) include IMO General Declaration, Ship's Stores, Crew List, Passenger List, ISPS pre-registration, pre-transfer/during transfer checklists.
Pre-arrival report via PortBase required for ships > 300 GT at Port of Rotterdam, 24 hours before Pilot Boarding Place, including detailed ship information.
General cargo vessel documentation at Port of Rotterdam includes IOPP, SOPEP, dangerous goods, and fumigants certificates.
Secure Chain process via PortBase for container release at Port of Rotterdam replaces PIN codes. Cargo Controller/Release Manager registration required.
Customs inspections at Port of Rotterdam often use scans at terminals. Physical inspections possible. Importer pays for 3rd party inspection costs.
Customs Administration of the Netherlands (Douane) oversees Dutch customs regulations for Port of Rotterdam.
Container Release Message (CVB) is mandatory for goods imported from outside the EU into Port of Rotterdam.
Import declaration must be filed electronically with Dutch Customs for goods entering Port of Rotterdam. EORI number is mandatory.
Dutch Customs enforce regulations on restricted and prohibited goods (counterfeit, protected species, weapons, drugs) at Port of Rotterdam.
The term 'port' in Rotterdam Port By-Laws includes waters, harbours, waterways, and associated structures within municipal boundaries, as defined in Article 1.1.
The captain or skipper is primarily responsible for compliance with Rotterdam Port By-Laws, as stated in Article 1.3.
The municipal executive decides on authorisation requests within 8 weeks, with a possible 8-week extension, as per Article 1.4 of Rotterdam Port By-Laws.
Authorisations related to a vessel must be retained on board as a digital or hard copy, as per Article 1.8 of Rotterdam Port By-Laws (excluding barges).
Compliance with traffic signs stated in Inland Waterways Police Regulations (BPR) and any additional particulars is mandatory in Port of Rotterdam, as per Article 3.1.

The municipal executive can designate areas where certain vessel categories may or may not berth, or where specific activities are permitted or prohibited, as per Article 3.2 of Rotterdam Port By-Laws.

Vessels may only berth in Port of Rotterdam if in compliance with traffic signs/notices, or with consent of berthing facility owner, unless prohibited by the municipal executive for safety or efficiency reasons, as per Article 3.3.
Proper and safe mooring of vessels is mandatory in Port of Rotterdam, as per Article 3.4.

Captains, operators, or agents of sea-going vessels must notify the harbour master of arrival, departure, and shifting, providing information determined by the municipal executive, as per Article 3.10.
Allowing substances to escape from a vessel that cause hazard, damage, or hindrance is prohibited in Port of Rotterdam, as per Article 4.1.
Using waste incinerators on board vessels in Port of Rotterdam is prohibited, as per Article 4.1.

The municipal executive may designate areas in Port of Rotterdam where generator use is prohibited, except for brief periods before departure and after arrival in designated areas, as per Article 4.2.
Moored vessels in Port of Rotterdam must provide safe access, as per Article 4.4, unless impossible due to loading/unloading or short mooring duration (inland vessels).

relevant_entity: Parties Conducting Activities on Sea-going Vessels
regulation_detail: For certain activities on sea-going vessels (defined in Article 4.5), notification to the harbour master is required prior to starting the activities, as per Article 4.5.5.
Reception of ship-generated waste in Port of Rotterdam is only permitted if the reception facility has a permit from the municipal executive, as per Article 4.8.
The harbour master must be notified prior to any cleaning or venting of tanker cargo tanks or slop tanks in Port of Rotterdam, as per Article 4.11.7.
Only tankers and specific other vessel types (defined in Article 5.2) are permitted in petroleumhavens in Port of Rotterdam.
Use of open flame, smoking outdoors, and spark-generating activities are prohibited in petroleumhavens in Port of Rotterdam, as per Article 5.3.
Tankers with dangerous substances must generally berth at petroleumhavens in Port of Rotterdam, as per Article 5.4.
Sea-going tankers with limited dangerous goods berthing outside petroleumhavens in Port of Rotterdam require a 'gas expert certificate', as per Article 5.6.
Bunkering or debunkering of designated fuels/energy sources in Port of Rotterdam requires a permit from the municipal executive, as per Article 8.1.
Completing and complying with a bunkering or debunkering checklist (established by municipal executive) is mandatory in Port of Rotterdam, as per Article 8.7.3.
Bunkering or debunkering checklists must be kept on board vessels concerned for at least 24 hours after the operation in Port of Rotterdam, as per Article 8.7.3.
Notifications to the harbour master are mandatory prior to and on completion of bunkering, debunkering, or ancillary substance transfer in Port of Rotterdam, as per Article 8.9.
Make agreements with all chain parties regarding mutual expectations in inland container shipping in Port of Rotterdam, as recommended by Inland Container Shipping Guidelines.

Share information and documents in a timely manner with chain parties in inland container shipping in Port of Rotterdam to optimize capacity use, as recommended by Inland Container Shipping Guidelines.

Inform barge operators/inland terminals immediately about ETA/ETD changes of sea-going vessels to optimize inland container shipping planning in Port of Rotterdam, as recommended by Inland Container Shipping Guidelines.

Discuss container 'lead time' (sea port to unloading address/vice versa) with barge operators/inland terminals when making contractual agreements for inland container shipping in Port of Rotterdam, as recommended by Inland Container Shipping Guidelines.
Make known container priorities to barge operators to optimize scheduling and port calls for inland container shipping in Port of Rotterdam, as recommended by Inland Container Shipping Guidelines.
The Eurogeul deep-water channel in Port of Rotterdam has a guaranteed depth of 25 meters.
source_document: Perplexity Web Search - "Vessel Size Limitations and Navigation Requirements at the Port of Rotterdam" Report

regulation_detail: The Eurogeul deep-water channel in Port of Rotterdam extends for 57 kilometers in length.
source_document: Perplexity Web Search - "Vessel Size Limitations and Navigation Requirements at the Port of Rotterdam" Report

regulation_detail: The Eurogeul channel in Port of Rotterdam is primarily used by deep-draught vessels such as large container ships, oil tankers, and ore carriers.
source_document: Perplexity Web Search - "Vessel Size Limitations and Navigation Requirements at the Port of Rotterdam" Report

regulation_detail: Vessels with a minimum draught of 17.4 meters are REQUIRED to use the Eurogeul channel when entering or leaving the Port of Rotterdam.
source_document: Perplexity Web Search - "Vessel Size Limitations and Navigation Requirements at the Port of Rotterdam" Report

regulation_detail: Deep-draught vessels requiring Eurogeul use are designated as 'geulers' or 'channel vessels' by Rotterdam Port VTS operators.
source_document: Perplexity Web Search - "Vessel Size Limitations and Navigation Requirements at the Port of Rotterdam" Report

regulation_detail: Access to specialized petroleumhavens like Nijlhaven and Yukonhaven in Rotterdam is restricted to vessels authorized for LNG operations (loading, unloading, bunkering).
source_document: Perplexity Web Search - "Vessel Size Limitations and Navigation Requirements at the Port of Rotterdam" Report

regulation_detail: The Port of Rotterdam features the Container Exchange Route (CER), an 11.5-kilometer dedicated road for efficient in-port container movement between terminals and modalities.
source_document: Perplexity Web Search - "Procedures and Documentation for Container Transhipment in the Port of Rotterdam" Report

regulation_detail: Port of Rotterdam provides 25 multi-user berths across various port areas specifically designed for efficient ship-to-ship container transhipment operations.
source_document: Perplexity Web Search - "Procedures and Documentation for Container Transhipment in the Port of Rotterdam" Report

regulation_detail: Container transhipment operations in Rotterdam require documentation to reflect 'Sea in/Sea out' status in the Portbase register.
source_document: Perplexity Web Search - "Procedures and Documentation for Container Transhipment in the Port of Rotterdam" Report

regulation_detail: Port of Rotterdam offers a transhipment discount for loaded containers with 'Sea in/Sea out' status in Portbase, moving between deep-sea and feeder services.
source_document: Perplexity Web Search - "Procedures and Documentation for Container Transhipment in the Port of Rotterdam" Report

regulation_detail: Portbase serves as the primary digital platform for documentation exchange and 'Sea in/Sea out' status registration for container transhipment operations in Port of Rotterdam.
source_document: Perplexity Web Search - "Procedures and Documentation for Container Transhipment in the Port of Rotterdam" Report

regulation_detail: PortXchange Pronto is an OPTIONAL digital platform in Rotterdam for port call optimization and data exchange, potentially useful for coordinating complex transhipment operations.
source_document: Perplexity Web Search - "Procedures and Documentation for Container Transhipment in the Port of Rotterdam" Report

regulation_detail: KING online reservation system is used for 24/7 booking of dedicated ship-to-ship transhipment berths in Port of Rotterdam.
source_document: Perplexity Web Search - "Procedures and Documentation for Container Transhipment in the Port of Rotterdam" Report

regulation_detail: Container terminals in Port of Rotterdam typically offer a standard free time period for container storage, ranging from a few days to a week.
source_document: Perplexity Web Search - "Regulations and Tariff Structures for Extended Container Storage in the Port of Rotterdam" Report

regulation_detail: Extended storage charges are levied on containers stored beyond the standard free time at Port of Rotterdam terminals. Rates vary by terminal and container type.
source_document: Perplexity Web Search - "Regulations and Tariff Structures for Extended Container Storage in the Port of Rotterdam" Report

regulation_detail: Container storage tariffs and regulations in Port of Rotterdam are typically terminal-specific (e.g., ECT, APMT, RWG have their own policies).
source_document: Perplexity Web Search - "Regulations and Tariff Structures for Extended Container Storage in the Port of Rotterdam" Report

regulation_detail: Official schedules of Rotterdam port storage fees and terminal-specific regulations can be found on terminal websites, or by contacting terminals/logistics providers directly.
source_document: Perplexity Web Search - "Regulations and Tariff Structures for Extended Container Storage in the Port of Rotterdam" Report

regulation_detail: Example extended storage charge at Port of Rotterdam: approximately €20 per day for a standard 20-foot container beyond the free storage period (rates vary).
source_document: Perplexity Web Search - "Regulations and Tariff Structures for Extended Container Storage in the Port of Rotterdam" Report

regulation_detail: Nextlogic is an integrated planning system in Port of Rotterdam for inland container shipping, optimizing vessel handling efficiency by matching supply and demand.
source_document: Perplexity Web Search - "Inland Container Logistics at Port of Rotterdam: Operational Systems and Best Practices" Report

regulation_detail: Nextlogic system features collaborative information sharing (barge rotations, terminal capacity), optimized scheduling, and 15-minute updates for inland container shipping planning in Rotterdam.
source_document: Perplexity Web Search - "Inland Container Logistics at Port of Rotterdam: Operational Systems and Best Practices" Report

regulation_detail: Approximately 60% of inland container shipping volume in Port of Rotterdam is planned through the Nextlogic system, with expanding participation.
source_document: Perplexity Web Search - "Inland Container Logistics at Port of Rotterdam: Operational Systems and Best Practices" Report

regulation_detail: KING online booking system in Rotterdam manages reservations for public buoy spans and dolphin berths used for ship-to-ship transhipment.
source_document: Perplexity Web Search - "Inland Container Logistics at Port of Rotterdam: Operational Systems and Best Practices" Report

regulation_detail: KING berth bookings in Rotterdam must be made online by ship agents, providing vessel names and adhering to cluster-specific deadlines (7-14 days prior to ETA).
source_document: Perplexity Web Search - "Inland Container Logistics at Port of Rotterdam: Operational Systems and Best Practices" Report

regulation_detail: Navigate online orientation tool in Port of Rotterdam provides route planning for deep sea, short sea, rail, and barge transport, including transit times and depot locations.
source_document: Perplexity Web Search - "Inland Container Logistics at Port of Rotterdam: Operational Systems and Best Practices" Report

regulation_detail: Port Call Optimization (PCO) system in Rotterdam collects/shares dynamic port call data, static data (tides), to improve vessel scheduling and reduce port stay time.
source_document: Perplexity Web Search - "Inland Container Logistics at Port of Rotterdam: Operational Systems and Best Practices" Report

regulation_detail: Rotterdam's Inland Container Shipping Guidelines recommend agreements, lead time consideration, demurrage/detention parameter setting, and information sharing for efficient inland container transport.
source_document: Perplexity Web Search - "Inland Container Logistics at Port of Rotterdam: Operational Systems and Best Practices" Report

regulation_detail: Rotterdam Logistics Lab is a Port of Rotterdam initiative creating an ecosystem for real-time data exchange and digitization in logistics operations through pilot projects.
source_document: Perplexity Web Search - "Inland Container Logistics at Port of Rotterdam: Operational Systems and Best Practices" Report

regulation_detail: Threshold-based repositioning strategy in Rotterdam reduces empty container storage costs by 18-22% and carbon emissions by 15-20% compared to non-repositioning.
source_document: Perplexity Web Search - "Rotterdam Port's Empty Container Repositioning Strategies..." Report

regulation_detail: Complete repositioning networks with full container sharing in Rotterdam achieve lowest operational costs (23% below threshold models) and 30% carbon emission reduction.
source_document: Perplexity Web Search - "Rotterdam Port's Empty Container Repositioning Strategies..." Report

regulation_detail: Direct depot-to-depot transfers for empty containers in Rotterdam achieve 15% cost savings and enhance turnaround by 2-3 days by eliminating intermediate port stops.
source_document: Perplexity Web Search - "Rotterdam Port's Empty Container Repositioning Strategies..." Report

regulation_detail: For empty container repositioning in Rotterdam, set explicit demurrage agreements with shipping companies using actual lead time data, not standard clauses, as a best practice.
source_document: Perplexity Web Search - "Rotterdam Port's Empty Container Repositioning Strategies..." Report

regulation_detail: Genetic algorithm models (e.g., MATLAB-based) can forecast container demand with 92% accuracy and enable real-time adjustment of repositioning thresholds in Rotterdam.
source_document: Perplexity Web Search - "Rotterdam Port's Empty Container Repositioning Strategies..." Report

regulation_detail: Port cooperation agreements for empty container repositioning in Rotterdam should specify carbon cost allocation formulas and emergency leasing protocols.
source_document: Perplexity Web Search - "Rotterdam Port's Empty Container Repositioning Strategies..." Report

regulation_detail: Rotterdam Port By-Laws mandate clean engines for inland vessels entering the port from 2025, requiring compliance with Phase II Rhine standards or Directive 97/68/EC.
Green Award certificate (plus CCR2 compliance) is required for inland vessels to access maximum incentives under Rotterdam's clean engine regulations, verifying emission standards and safety.
ESI-NOx Index certification validates NOx reduction performance for inland vessels using LNG or catalytic converters in Rotterdam, contributing to incentive eligibility.
RFNBO certification (Renewable Fuels of Non-Biological Origin) is mandatory for inland vessels using renewable hydrogen-based fuels in Rotterdam, requiring auditing via EC-recognized schemes.
Verified Bunker Delivery Notes (BDNs) showing fuel sulfur content ≤0.1% are required documentation for inland vessels in Rotterdam's Emission Control Areas.
Inland vessels with Green Award certification (plus CCR2) receive up to 30% discount on port dues in Rotterdam, along with priority bunkering slots.
Non-compliant inland vessel operators in Rotterdam face 15% surcharges on port dues and restricted access to prime terminal slots under clean engine regulations.
